blog.name: acepalindrome
blog.title: you're going to be something extraordinary
blog.description: Hello, this is Palindrome! I'm currently doing my best to pretend that I'm a functional and well adjusted adult, with varying levels of success! Around this neck of the woods you'll find history stuff, nature stuff, whatever fandoms I'm into at the moment, fanfics I write when I can muster up the energy, the occasional mental breakdown and a variety of fun facts I come across or things I find interesting. Feel free to follow or drop me a line, I promise I'm quite tame.

summary: I’m really looking forward to Matt’s Between the Sheets but I’m also afraid because he’s so full of love and kindness and my...
body: I’m really looking forward to Matt’s Between the Sheets but I’m also afraid because he’s so full of love and kindness and my fragile heart might not be able to handle it.

blog.name: the-scarecrowlover
blog.title: Ravenspire Keep
blog.description:
Home of the Scarecrowlover:
5e DM/Home-brewer
Casual Writer/Artist/Gamer
Aspiring Professor
...Nocturnal Creature...

title: Thank you, Vox Machina...
body:
My year-off between college and grad school was one of the lowest moments of my life. I had moved to my grandmother’s home in Italy to take care of her, as she had Parkinson, and her deteriorating state was hard to handle when I myself wasn’t in the best state of mind.

I felt lost. What I had initially assumed to be post-graduation depression soon spiraled into a resonating sense of existential dread. I was unemployed and unsure about my future. I spent 20 hours a day in bed and estranged my friends. I fought to accept my newly discovered asexuality and gender identity and grieved over the fact that I hadn’t discovered it sooner. The abuse and suffering I’d experienced during my brief life felt heavier on my conscious than ever before, and I wished my life would end before it fully consumed me.

But then, one day, out of the blue, something strange happened: A very random acquaintance that I had not spoken to for more than two years hit me up on messenger saying, unprompted: “You should watch this show called Critical Role, you’d like it.”

It’s not like I had anything else to do with my life. I hadn’t touched D&D in more than a decade, and since I did indeed enjoy watching people play videogames on YouTube, I figured I’d give it a shot. To this day, I still can’t believe I almost stopped watching after the first episode. I was having a bad day and my patience had been tried during the first combat scene. The next day, I gave it another shot, when I was in a better mood. And then I kept on watching…and kept on watching, and kept on watching… for two months straight.

Critical Role was the first thing I’d see when I woke up. I’d take a quick break to do human things like eating, bathing, and fixing my grandmother’s heater, but then I’d dive right back in. I told myself I wasn’t allowed to watch a new episode after 2AM, but even then I sometimes couldn’t resist. It was the ultimate escapist activity. I once told my grandma I was going out with friends so she wouldn’t worry about me, when in reality I hid away in the garage under the apartment where I could still use the wifi and watched another episode. By the time I caught up, Vox Machina has just visited Marquet, and felt like my world was going to fall apart because I couldn’t binge new content anymore.

But my world didn’t fall apart. I did what any sane person would do and simply decided watch it all over again, which was oddly rewarding because I was now watching it with Dungeon Master eyes, and could see all the little tidbits of foreshadowing.  And then I watched it again…but this time while recording trivia facts, because why not?

Needless to say,  I kept myself busy. I felt like a child again, discovering something that I wanted to explore with all of my imagination. I started drawing again, and writing again. I drew portrait Percy on the backside of an expired document: it was the first drawing I had done in almost two years. I wrote a quick little fanfiction blurbs that I didn’t publish, but that I liked enough to save on a computer.

When I felt like I was running out of things to do, I did not fall into despair like I initially predicted. Instead, another strange thing happened: I started going out more. I was actually excited to tell my friends about this new show I was watching, even if it was foreign and bizarre to southern Italians. But then I discovered that some of my friends did know what D&D was, and I told them I wanted to try being a dungeon master again. We ended up making a group and playing once a week for 7 hours a day for 5 months. It was the happiest I had ever been in a long long time. I felt like I had purpose, and something to look forward to. I told myself I’d put off committing suicide until after Critical Role was over.

On my plane ride back to California, I started writing a comprehensive Modern Adaptation of the Vox Machina saga as writing practice. I enjoyed exploring the character’s personalities in a magicless modern setting. I found the character studies to be incredibly rewarding and a means of practicing my craft. The fact that others liked what I wrote was more than a convenient bonus: It made me realize that there were people out there who actually looked forward to reading the next chapter of something I had created. I once got a comment that was three pages long, and I almost cried. It meant that I now had something else I needed to finish before I killed myself. It wasn’t just for me anymore: This was for all of those who could relate to the struggles of young adults trying to make due in a pre-dystopian reality, struggling with money, drugs, love, family, self-identity, purpose, and the evils of the powerful hellbent on exploiting the weak and the underprivileged. (I’d be lying if I said I wasn’t inspired by today’s current political climate… Corporations make for fantastic “dragons”).

At first, I worried that the end of the first campaign would be the end of me, but it wasn’t. By the time we said goodbye to Vox Machina, I was in grad school, and I no longer had time to think about suicide. I was too busy thinking about midterms, and the next story beat in my D&D home game, and how I was going to translate the demon attack on Uriel’s family in a modern setting.

But Critical Role and the cast did so much more for me than just keep me alive: It helped me better understand what it meant to be an independent young adult; it showed me what healthy relationships were supposed to look like; it gave me the realization that friends could be family. D&D was the vessel that allowed me to meet my Queer Platonic Partner. Critical Role even taught me what “impostor syndrome” was, which in turn put me on the right track toward recovery (albeit after nice long crying session, because that’s apparently something that happens when you find a word for something that has been haunting you for years). But Critical Role also helped me process more immediate life events, such as the death of my grandfather, with more emotional clarity. His situation paralleled Vax’s in many ways: We knew it was gonna happen, but it still hurt when it did. Critical Role helped me understand that what I was feeling was normal. Even heroes cried.

I can’t believe I’ve been working on this modern adaptation of the Vox Machina saga for two years now, because I’ve never been able to stick with something for longer than six months. It is now longer that the Fellowship of the Ring, and I haven’t even gotten into steam-content yet. Which is good, I suppose… It just means I a lot to write before I can say “I’ve done everything life has to offer. Now I can kill myself.” So in a way, I thank the cast of Critical Role for making such a long and elaborate story for me to adapt. You’ve extended my life by what I expect to be at least a decade, if not more.

It’s nice though. I have been enjoying my time here. I’m on my last semester of grad school, and I decided to take a basic drawing class because I’d like to get better so I can maybe make some money off of it. I started working on a lot of other writing projects that are not fanfiction, including my fantasy saga, which I revisited when I realized I still loved fantasy. Recently I came up with the entire plot of a horror story I plan on turning into a novel or novella. Things are actually looking bright, for once.

I want to believe that I probably would have snapped out of my funk on my own, but honestly, I think Critical Role may have legitimately prolonged my life, and for that, I thank you, Vox Machina.

It’s not like I had anything else to do with my life. But my world didn’t fall apart. I did what any sane person would do and simply decided watch it all over again, which was oddly rewarding because I was now watching it with Dungeon Master eyes, and could see all the little tidbits of foreshadowing.  And then I watched it again…but this time while recording trivia facts, because why not?

Needless to say,  I kept myself busy. I felt like a child again, discovering something that I wanted to explore with all of my imagination. I started drawing again, and writing again. I drew portrait Percy on the backside of an expired document: it was the first drawing I had done in almost two years. I wrote a quick little fanfiction blurbs that I didn’t publish, but that I liked enough to save on a computer.

When I felt like I was running out of things to do, I did not fall into despair like I initially predicted. Instead, another strange thing happened: I started going out more. I was actually excited to tell my friends about this new show I was watching, even if it was foreign and bizarre to southern Italians. But then I discovered that some of my friends did know what D&D was, and I told them I wanted to try being a dungeon master again. We ended up making a group and playing once a week for 7 hours a day for 5 months. It was the happiest I had ever been in a long long time. I felt like I had purpose, and something to look forward to. I told myself I’d put off committing suicide until after Critical Role was over.

I enjoyed exploring the character’s personalities in a magicless modern setting. I found the character studies to be incredibly rewarding and a means of practicing my craft. The fact that others liked what I wrote was more than a convenient bonus: It made me realize that there were people out there who actually looked forward to reading the next chapter of something I had created. I once got a comment that was three pages long, and I almost cried. It meant that I now had something else I needed to finish before I killed myself. It wasn’t just for me anymore: This was for all of those who could relate to the struggles of young adults trying to make due in a pre-dystopian reality, struggling with money, drugs, love, family, self-identity, purpose, and the evils of the powerful hellbent on exploiting the weak and the underprivileged. (I’d be lying if I said I wasn’t inspired by today’s current political climate… Corporations make for fantastic “dragons”).

But Critical Role also helped me process more immediate life events, such as the death of my grandfather, with more emotional clarity. His situation paralleled Vax’s in many ways: We knew it was gonna happen, but it still hurt when it did. Critical Role helped me understand that what I was feeling was normal. Even heroes cried.

I can’t believe I’ve been working on this modern adaptation of the Vox Machina saga for two years now, because I’ve never been able to stick with something for longer than six months. It is now longer that the Fellowship of the Ring, and I haven’t even gotten into steam-content yet. Which is good, I suppose… It just means I a lot to write before I can say “I’ve done everything life has to offer. Now I can kill myself.” So in a way, I thank the cast of Critical Role for making such a long and elaborate story for me to adapt. You’ve extended my life by what I expect to be at least a decade, if not more.

It’s nice though. I have been enjoying my time here. I’m on my last semester of grad school, and I decided to take a basic drawing class because I’d like to get better so I can maybe make some money off of it. I started working on a lot of other writing projects that are not fanfiction, including my fantasy saga, which I revisited when I realized I still loved fantasy. Recently I came up with the entire plot of a horror story I plan on turning into a novel or novella. Things are actually looking bright, for once.

I want to believe that I probably would have snapped out of my funk on my own, but honestly, I think Critical Role may have legitimately prolonged my life, and for that, I thank you, Vox Machina.

body:
Fun little thought

Just a small real quick post probably not right but i think Jamedi is a vampire and that Beau aching all over was from the blood loss. Because those are things that blood loss can do to a person and an undead in the group is a little freaky. Probably wrong but i just find it interesting to think that Beau got bit my Jamedi the vampire.

summary: So... this is the last in my Mighty Nein Music Box series.  The irony of finishing this series on the anniversary of Vox...
caption:
So… this is the last in my Mighty Nein Music Box series.  The irony of finishing this series on the anniversary of Vox Machina’s final chapter doesn’t escape me, but I guess that’s how we’re doing this.

Closing us out is Caduceus, with a gently creepy melody for a gently creepy firbolg grave cleric.  Thank you, Taliesin Jaffe, for whatever that sentence translates to.  (Bonus points to anyone who can spot the reference to Molly’s melody I snuck in here).

Special thanks to @coslyons for the insight on this melody.  

The Mighty Nein Music Box Roundup:  Kiri | Molly | Jester | Nott | Caleb | Beau | Fjord | Yasha

tags: i still need to catch up but
I began where the first campaign ended
summary: Ironically, today is the first anniversary of the first campaign's ending. It's the first day that I saw Critical Role trending...
body: Ironically, today is the first anniversary of the first campaign’s ending. It’s the first day that I saw Critical Role trending on Tumblr, #1 I believe, and the first thought that spawned an obsession with Dungeons and Dragons and DnD streams was, “Why is Liam O'Brien crying, haven’t he suffered enough in life? Wait, there’s fucking LAURA BAILEY, TRAVIS WILLINGHAM? Oh my shit, that’s THE Taliesin Jaffe? What the fuck is this?”

summary: One year ago we said goodbye to Vox Machina. I just want to say thank you for this great story that I will always cherish in my...
body:
One year ago we said goodbye to Vox Machina. I just want to say thank you for this great story that I will always cherish in my heart. I miss these characters so much, but will remember them for a long time. Critical Role and Vox Machina made my life so much better and I’ll be grateful for this forever.

And every day this raven comes to visit…

blog.name: flightofstars
blog.title: Flight of Stars: Let's Write Together

summary: Fic Post: [Critical Role] Eight of Swords - Chapter 7 has updated!
title: Fic Post: [Critical Role] Eight of Swords - Chapter 7 has updated!
body:
Chapter Summary: Caleb wakes up for the first time after being healed, and Fjord struggles to fully explain what happened.

Excerpt:

A slow consideration followed. It was so good to see him thinking coherently, Fjord wasn’t prepared for what he asked next. “Is everyone alright, then?”

Fjord didn’t understand. “Everyone?”

A terrible understanding came over Fjord. When Caleb went under, the four of them had been together in the warehouse. As far as he knew, they’d still been there when the attack came. How did Fjord even begin to explain the truth? He looked at Nott, who was gazing at him accusingly. ‘Explain yourself,’ she seemed to say, but what actually came out of her mouth was, “Everyone is alright, Caleb. We can talk more later, after you rest.”

Read chapter 4: here (Ao3) or here (FF.net)

summary: VOX MACHINA FOREVER.  This show saved me in a dark period of my life. When I felt nothing I did amounted to anything and anxiety...
caption:
VOX MACHINA FOREVER. 

This show saved me in a dark period of my life. When I felt nothing I did amounted to anything and anxiety had made give up ever role playing again. In a few weeks I am sitting down rolling physical dice for the the first time in 4 years.

summary: The disease Beau caught last night sounds a lot like the Shivering Sickness from Tomb of Annihilation: Insects native to the...
body:
The disease Beau caught last night sounds a lot like the Shivering Sickness from Tomb of Annihilation:

Insects native to the jungles and marshes of Chult carry this disease, shivering sickness. The easiest protection against it is a coating of insect-repelling salve on all exposed skin (for the cost of insect repellent, see “Buying a Special Item”).

A giant or humanoid that takes damage from insect swarms or from giant centipedes, giant scorpions, or giant wasps is exposed to the disease at the end of the encounter. Those who haven’t applied insect repellent since their previous long rest are exposed to the disease when they finish a long rest.

A giant or humanoid exposed to the disease must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution saving throw or become infected. A creature with natural armor has advantage on the saving throw. It takes 2d6 hours for symptoms to manifest in an infected creature. Symptoms include blurred vision, disorientation, and a sudden drop in body temperature that causes uncontrollable shivering and chattering of the teeth.

Once symptoms begin, the infected creature regains only half the normal number of hit points from spending Hit Dice and no hit points from a long rest. The infected creature also has disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls. At the end of a long rest, an infected creature repeats the saving throw, shaking off the disease on a successful save.

It’s not a perfect match of course but it’s very close! Especially considering they’re in a jungle and there were multiple mentions of bugs.

Bixbi, older than you.

Fat queer of indeterminate origin.

Possibly a lesser demon.

Hellenist serving Hestia, Hermes and Chiron.

Critical Role has taken over my life and my blog.

Taliesin Jaffe is my boyfriend.

I love you.

#eyesnevershut

summary: A SORDID AFFAIR UPDATE The one where Vex took Saundor's deal and Percy let Orthax consume his soul. The Modern AU version,...
caption:
A SORDID AFFAIR UPDATE

The one where Vex took Saundor’s deal and Percy let Orthax consume his soul.

The Modern AU version, anyway.

Critical Role || Perc’ahlia

Chapter 13. she’s running the game

In the end, Vex broke the news to Vax about their father the only way she knew how—over a bottle of scotch and a night filled with much cursing and just a bit of crying.

He took it rather well, all things considered. A testament to his newfound optimism, she supposed.

Part of her hated that he was so mellow about it all, that he wasn’t losing his mind like she’d lost hers. The rest of her, however, was so abundantly happy for him that she shoved that other part down into the depths of her heart and strangled it until she could smile at him and mean it.

Something had clicked in her mind after Keyleth’s party. Spending time with her friends, her friends, not just Vax’s friends, had reminded her who she was supposed to be under all the glamour and edge. Who she’d been before Syldor, before that blood-drenched night three years ago which had changed the trajectory of her life for good. The girl who still cried sometimes at night when she remembered her mother’s smile, and the sound of her voice. The girl who’d stuck feathers in her hair and collected twigs in the forest behind their house, using the scent of a baking pie to tell her if she was straying too far.

The girl who’d still dreamed of a father who loved her.

Read the rest on AO3.

Like what I do? Consider supporting me on Ko-fi <3

A SORDID AFFAIR UPDATE

The Modern AU version, anyway.

Critical Role || Perc’ahlia

Chapter 13. she’s running the game

In the end, Vex broke the news to Vax about their father the only way she knew how—over a bottle of scotch and a night filled with much cursing and just a bit of crying.

He took it rather well, all things considered. A testament to his newfound optimism, she supposed.

Part of her hated that he was so mellow about it all, that he wasn’t losing his mind like she’d lost hers. The rest of her, however, was so abundantly happy for him that she shoved that other part down into the depths of her heart and strangled it until she could smile at him and mean it.

body:

Thank you for following me and my weird mix of dnd/game grumps/crit role/ the adventure zone blog! You guys are great
